Grades 4-6 Families,
Thank you for your patience as we have worked to develop and implement our reopening plan. We know that a technology survey went out earlier this summer, however, throughout our planning process we have found that it will be vital for our students to have computer access at home and in school.

We are asking that you complete this form to let us know if you have a personal device (Chromebook or laptop) that you are comfortable allowing your child to bring back and forth to school or if you need a school-issued device.

We will have a device pick-up time on Tuesday, Sept. 8th and Wednesday, Sept. 9th. from 3:00-5:00 pm. Parents who indicate the need for a device can pick it up any time during the pick-up window at the CES main office entrance. Students will need a device in order to access learning activities on the first day of school, whether in-person or remote.

Please fill out one form per child.

Skyler Misiaszek is beginning her Girl Scout Gold Award Project “PIT STOP”, which has been approved by the Girl Scout Regional Board. Skyler is starting a Can and Bottle Drive on Monday, August 3 to raise funds to achieve her goal of purchasing at least one set of bleachers for the Maple Hill High School track.

These bleachers will provide a place for elderly and/or physically challenged patrons to sit as they cheer on their Maple Hill Wildcats!

Maple Hill Wildcats or town residents can email Skyler at pkmisiaszek@nycap.rr.com to arrange for a pick-up. She will go to the person’s house, or place of business, to pick up the cans and bottles and deliver them to the recycling center. Participants can also deliver the cans or bottles themselves to The Bottle & Can Company of East Greenbush at 594 Columba Turnpike in East Greenbush. Be sure to let the receiver know that the items are for “PIT STOP”.

Schodack CSD would like to reassure our community after receiving a few questions from residents who received absentee ballots for individuals who do not live at a home.

When New York State ordered school districts in May to mail absentee ballots to all qualified voters, the district used voting information from county Boards of Elections and poll lists from the past two years' school budget votes. Unfortunately, outdated voting information resulted in additional ballots mailed to some homes. If this occurs, please destroy incorrect ballots.

Please know we are confident in the voting process because each voter must read and sign the voter statement, which notes returning a false ballot violates election law. If you have any questions, please call the District Office at 518-732-2297. Thank you.

Schodack CSD would like to share information with our families about a safety concern that could impact our students.

The Schodack Police Department has received information that there is a mass group text regarding the planning of a large "Hide and Seek" competition apparently to take place at the old Fort Orange property. We have information that the text is apparently being circulated to Maple Hill 9th graders and possibly others.

This poses a significant safety issue for many reasons and potentially puts the officers in a dangerous situation as well. Anyone caught on the property could also be charged with trespassing.

Schodack CSD and Schodack Police want to share this information with our families as we work together to keep our students safe. Thank you.

Voting will take place only through absentee ballot, as directed by Governor Andrew Cuomo's executive order. Qualified voters on the most recent years' poll lists will be automatically sent an absentee ballot. More information is available on our website, including an online form to request additional ballots.

We will share information about the 2020-21 school budget as soon as we know more. The Board of Education is waiting until May 19 to adopt a budget in order to gather more information about state aid. Governor Cuomo is expected to announce in the next week or so whether funding for education will be cut further due to the state budget deficit. Thank you.

Each year, the district's Information Technology Department visits 1st grade classrooms to teach students about computers and share how the district's technology works.

Showing students the insides of computers, tablets and other hardware, Computer Network Manager Jim Yox and Computer Network Administrator Matt Purificato shared how much technology has evolved and gotten so much smaller over the years.

Students also learned how information travels as Mr. Yox and Mr. Purificato described how a student making a request from a device travels through the district's network all the way to Google headquarters in California and back seemingly instantaneously.

"That's so cool!" said one student.

"That's crazy!" said another.

Thank you Mr. Yox and Mr. Purificato for visiting with our students!

Castleton Elementary School kicked off its Wellness Week today, a week of fun activities designed to promote physical and emotional well-being for students. Monday's theme was Music where students in each grade took part in activities designed for their age level.

Kindergartners and first graders, for example, listened to sounds and music and then were asked to describe how it made them feel. Students then had a chance to move around, galloping, hopping or running in place to the sounds or music that were played.

"You just worked your mind because you were listening and you just worked your heart because you were exercising," Physical Therapist Jamie Colloton told students.

Schodack CSD wants to reassure our community about an issue at Maple Hill Jr./Sr. High School this morning where an odor was detected in the auditorium.

As soon as we noticed the odor, we moved a class that was scheduled to use the auditorium to the cafeteria to investigate the cause. After checking the school's boiler room, kitchen, and crawl space under the building, we determined the cause of the odor was changes to the basement ventilation that were made Thursday. We reversed those changes, which resolved the issue. As a precaution, we installed carbon monoxide and natural gas detectors in the auditorium and adjoining band room, which indicated no issues. Please know there was no risk to student or staff safety.

If anyone has questions, please contact Director of Facilities Matt LaClair at 518-813-6414 who would be happy to answer them. Thank you.

Castleton Elementary School students spent time learning from two Yale University scientists today.

Chemist Hannah Lant and Quantum Physicist Chris Wang visited the school to discuss their work, lead experiments and answer questions about their experiences in the field of science.

Ms. Lant showed the type of work she does in a laboratory by involving students in an experiment to split water using common items such as pencils in a solution that was connected to a small battery. Mr. Wang discussed his work to create a quantum computer that is more powerful than a standard computer, sharing a piece of his work.

The two graduate students were invited to the school by Innovative Learning Lab Teacher Sarah Lant.

Thank you for teaching our students about the world of science today!
